H0.text: Genetic drift is the phenomenon most important in small populations that occurs because the alleles in an offspring generation are a random sample of the alleles in the parent generation.

H1.text: Genetic DNA is the phenomenon most important in small populations that occurs because the alleles in an offspring generation are a random sample of the alleles in the parent generation.

H2.text: Genetic mutation is the phenomenon, most important in small populations, that occurs because the alleles in an offspring generation are a random sample of the alleles in the parent generation.

H3.text: Genetic code is the phenomenon, most important in small populations, that occurs because the alleles in an offspring generation are a random sample of the alleles in the parent generation.

A4.text: Genetic drift, also known as random genetic drift, allelic drift or the Wright effect, is the change in the frequency of an existing gene variant (allele) in a population due to random chance.

A5.text: The second jar will now contain 20 'offspring', or marbles of various colours. Unless the second jar contains exactly 10 red marbles and 10 blue marbles, a random shift has occurred in the allele frequencies.
